THE LIFE OF
  • A YOUNG MAN IN UNIFORM
  • AN ENGINEER IS BORN
  • A MILESTONE PROPOSAL
  • FIRST COMES HOME, THEN COMES MARRIAGE…
  • TYING THE KNOT, AND MOVING IN
  • A BABY ON THE WAY
  • MOVING ON UP! A SECOND HOME
  • BABY NUMBER TWO
  • NEW DECADE, NEW INVESTMENTS
  • SECOND-HAND NO MORE
  • THEY GROW UP SO FAST
  • RETIREMENT

Ryan Ang.

Ryan was born into a lower to middle class Singaporean family.  He grew up in public housing in a two bedroom HDB, and shared a room with his younger sister.

Ryan’s Singaporean parents have traditional values when it comes to money: work hard and save up. As an adolescent, Ryan went to public school and excelled in math and science.

Like many of his peers, during his upbringing Ryan felt pressured to excel academically and help launch his family to the next economic stratosphere. After completing his mandatory 2 years of service with the National Service, Ryan applied to the National University of Singapore (NUS) for Engineering and was awarded a STEM scholarship.

While completing his undergraduate studies, Ryan started dating his first girlfriend who later becomes his wife. After convocating with his undergraduate degree in Engineering, Ryan pursued his master’s degree at NTU in Computer Science.

A young man in uniform

Preparing to go into the National Service, Ryan looks forward to serving his country. However, for the first time in his life he is moved to consider the reality and potential consequences of serious injury, or even death.

After hearing some distressing stories he decides to do some research on extra health and life insurance. Ryan has little in the way of savings as this stage in his life, and this is the first time he has ever looked into any type of insurance on his own. He knows that the stipend he gets from NS will only be enough to cover transportation costs.

Healthcare and Life Insurance

An engineer is born

While attending graduate school, Ryan works part-time and lives with his parents to maximize his savings. He maintains the balance in his savings account, and primarily uses cash or a debit card for his day-to-day needs.

At 27, Ryan is proud to land his first job as a software engineer.  His first paycheck brings the happy realization that, for the first time in his life, he is earning more than he needs.

Credit Card Point Comparison

After treating his family to a celebratory dinner out, Ryan puts his mind to the question of how best to manage his extra earnings and how best to spend it.

Consumed with thoughts of future and family, Ryan decides that an engagement ring for his girlfriend Carrie will represent his first financial milestone. Convention advises that this ring should cost roughly the equivalent of 3 months of his current salary. 

"Will you HDB with me?"

With discipline and dedication to his savings plan, Ryan is able to purchase the ring he most wants to present to Carrie. He makes sure that the ring is insured for X value. This is a highly emotional time for Ryan as many of his accomplishments – professional, financial and personal – begin to bring him pride. As he musters up the courage to propose, Ryan is aware of the full transition he is making to adulthood.

Within months of their engagement, (yes, he got the answer he was hoping for!), Ryan and Carrie submit an application for a BTO (Build-To-Order) in a less mature HDB estate.  As first-timers applying for public housing in a non-mature estate, their chances are high. Six weeks after submitting their application, Ryan and Carrie find out that they have been approved.  The couple has 4 months to sign a lease and put a down payment on the BTO flat.

Their combined salaries qualify them for a mortgage and thanks to Carrie’s CPF, they can easily put forward a combined down payment which consists of 5% cash (20K), and 15% CPF (60K), on a flat that costs 400K. 

3D sequence

Mortgage Process

First comes home, then comes marriage.

Once engaged, Ryan and Carrie embark on some ambitious life planning which leaves them walking a financial tightrope.

If things go according to plan, Ryan and Carrie will collect the keys to their new home within a month of getting hitched.

As they wait for their home to be ready, they plan and save for several considerable costs, including a modest wedding and minor home renovations, before finally moving into their BTO and purchasing a car.

Throughout their time carefully researching the home buying process, Ryan and Carrie have learned that during the BTO application process, either a Whole or Term insurance policy fulfills the requirements for Home Protection Insurance, which is required by the HDB.

Product comparison

Tying the knot, and moving in.

After officially marrying with a modest ceremony, Ryan and Carrie are almost ready to move in. With so much happening at once and the renovation a little over budget, the couple’s finances are tighter than ever and Ryan takes out a small loan to help cover the cost of the wedding (about 15-20K). Soon after, the pair move in to their new home in Jurong West and begin anew phase of their journey together. Since getting approved on their BTO, Ryan has been researching cars as living further out in these less mature estates leaves them with limited transportation options. Ryan manages to find a second-hand car with a 7-year COE left on it.

Cut-diagram of car

A baby on the way.

Within 3 months of moving into their new home, Ryan and Carrie are delighted to find out that Carrie is pregnant.

While Ryan starts to plan for the arrival of their first baby, he consults with family and friends about what kinds of insurance and investment products he might need. On the most exciting and nerve-wracking day of his life, a hospital pamphlet reminds Ryan to set up Shawn’s, his newly born son’s, education fund.

A 2nd home.

After 5 years of living in their first flat together, Ryan and Carrie are ready for an upgrade, and look into investing in an Executive Condo. If Ryan puts their flat on the market, he can likely earn 550 - 600K, and with Carrie not working, they financially qualify for an EC.

Ryan doesn’t want to move too far from the location of their current home, and finds an EC that is only a street over for 700-800K.  Once the deal is sealed, the couple learns that Carrie is pregnant again.  Though ecstatic with the news, Ryan feels pressure to make more money so he can comfortably accommodate his growing family and increasing expenses. 

Shawn is here.

Now with two little children in the house, Ryan decides to get a domestic helper to help with chores and child-care. Having a family of four brings Ryan great pride and happiness, and he is moved to think of his children’s future health and prosperity.  Ryan’s financial plan is now seeing double, with two education funds, and two critical illness insurance plans.

Zoe
Shawn

Along with his children’s future, Ryan often turns his mind to his wife Carrie’s and his future retirement. Though happy with his financial progress, saving for the future along with child expenses sit heavily on Ryan’s conscience. He feels that these days he is spending, spending, spending.

New decade, new investments.

By his 40th birthday, Ryan has been a dedicated employee to his company for seven years, and is promoted. To celebrate, Ryan and Carrie go to Bali on vacation just the two of them; this is the first vacation they’ve had as a couple since the arrival of their children.

Upon their return, Ryan decides that the time is right for an additional investment. Ryan purchases a two-bedroom condo in Paya Lebar for $880K, and within six months after a quick renovation, the condo is renting for 2900 a month; which is just enough to cover the mortgage.

Chart

With a solid grip on his financial plan, and the recent sell of the old mini-van, Ryan decides for the first time ever in his life to purchase a brand-new car. After years of carefully planned second-hand purchasing, this car represents a special pleasure and proud accomplishment for Ryan. Dropping the kids, ages 11 and 9, at school suddenly takes on a new element of satisfaction.

They grow up so fast.

After what felt like a blink of his eye, Ryan’s children near completing their undergraduate studies. His daughter is at NTU and appears to be following her father’s footsteps. His own parents having passed away a few years earlier, Ryan now turns his mind to his own retirement.

In their final years, Ryan’s parents had no other option than to rely on Ryan for financial support. With his investments behaving as they should, and his fifties coming to a close, Ryan’s financial goals include preparation for his and Carrie’s final years, avoiding undue strain on their children for time and care.

Retirement.

At age 60, Ryan retires from full-time work, but keeps up part-time consulting on the side to keep his brain active. Both Shawn and Zoe have graduated from college, and Zoe has announced that she is engaged to be married.

Brimming with pride, it is Ryan’s task to consider whether he should liquidate some of his assets now, or incorporate them into his estate. His comfort in financial security, culminating in this happy decision, represents a lifetime of hard work well worth it.

At 65, Ryan meets his second grandson Desmond, and his Legacy Insurance kicks in. Carrie is a little slower these days, but her energy for her grandchildren seems magically unstoppable. As Ryan reposes into older age, he is struck by memories of his own childhood. Never could he have imagined, as a kid sharing a room in his family’s HDB, the scene he now has before him. As his own family grows and thrives, Ryan is proud, thankful, and at peace. He spends the rest of his days watching his family grow and thrive.
